title: Post 3: Real-Life Example: Technology Transfer Project
text:
Project Overview

Objective: Move and validate a micro-catheter production line from Shizuoka, Japan to Texas and Utah facilities.

Budget: $5 million

Timeline: 5 years

Stakeholders: R&D teams in Japan and the US, manufacturing, QA/RA, regulatory bodies, and executive leadership

title: Post 3: Real-Life Example: Technology Transfer Project
text:
PMBOK 7 in Action

1. Principles-Based Approach

Stewardship & Team Collaboration: Facilitated alignment across multinational teams, ensuring knowledge transfer and regulatory compliance.

Stakeholder Engagement: Regular briefings with executives and regulatory teams ensured buy-in and minimized resistance.



2. Performance Domains







Performance Domain
Example Activity




Delivery
Coordinated validation of equipment and production processes


Planning
Developed Gantt charts, resource plans, and risk logs


Risk & Uncertainty
Monitored supplier delays and regulatory risks, implemented mitigation plans


Team
Led cross-cultural teams across time zones, coached junior engineers





3. Value Delivery

Ensured the transfer aligned with corporate strategic goals.

Implemented metrics to track operational readiness and product quality post-transfer.

Achieved full production capability in the new facilities with minimal downtime.

title: Post 3: Real-Life Example: Technology Transfer Project
text:
Key Lessons Learned

Tailoring is Essential: Hybrid project management (Agile + Waterfall) helped adapt to unexpected equipment delays.

Communication Drives Success: Weekly cross-site video calls prevented misalignment between Japanese and US teams.

Principles Over Processes: Focusing on value and outcomes rather than strictly following prescriptive steps allowed flexibility to solve real-world challenges.

title: Post 3: Real-Life Example: Technology Transfer Project
text:
Reflection
This project illustrates how PMBOK 7 principles—stewardship, value delivery, and adaptability—are applied in high-stakes, regulated, and multinational environments.
It reinforces that a project manager’s role today is not just to execute tasks but to lead, adapt, and deliver measurable value.

title: Introduction to PMBOK for Modern Project Managers
text:
PMBOK has evolved dramatically over the last decade. What many of us learned as process groups, ITTOs, and detailed workflows has shifted into a broader, principle-driven view of project management that recognizes that no two projects look the same.
This post breaks down what PMBOK really is (and isn’t), why the 7th Edition shifted direction, and how to use PMBOK as a practical toolkit — not a rigid rulebook.

title: Introduction to PMBOK for Modern Project Managers
text:
12 Principles (Leadership Mindsets)

Stewardship

Team

Stakeholders

Value

Systems thinking

Tailoring

Quality

Complexity

Adaptability

Risk

Change

Delivering value

These are habits, not procedures.

title: Introduction to PMBOK for Modern Project Managers
text:
8 Performance Domains (Execution Realities)

Stakeholders

Team

Development Approach & Lifecycle

Planning

Project Work

Delivery

Measurement

Uncertainty/Risk

Domains represent ongoing areas of performance, not phases.

title: Post 2: What’s New in PMBOK 7th Edition?
text:
Introduction
The shift from the PMBOK Guide 6th Edition to PMBOK Guide 7th Edition is the most significant evolution in the Project Management Institute’s framework in decades.
Instead of adding more processes, artifacts, and prescribed tools, PMBOK 7 redefines project management around principles, value delivery, and adaptability.
This post breaks down what changed—and why these changes matter to modern project managers.



1. A Shift in Philosophy: Predictive → Flexible
Older editions of PMBOK assumed projects were largely predictable and process-driven.
But the modern environment? Fast-moving, uncertain, hybrid by default.
PMBOK 7 responds by shifting to a principle-based guide, making it methodology-agnostic and compatible with:

Agile

Waterfall

Hybrid

Lean

Systems engineering

Regulated environments

This flexibility supports real-world complexity instead of prescribing one way to work.



2. From 49 Processes → 12 Guiding Principles
PMBOK 6’s 49 processes are no longer the centerpiece.
PMBOK 7 organizes guidance around 12 principles, such as:

Stewardship

Team collaboration

Stakeholder engagement

Systems thinking

Adaptation

Quality and value delivery

These principles are meant to guide decision-making—not constrain it.

Note: The 49 processes still exist in PMI’s Standards+ library for reference.




3. From Knowledge Areas → Performance Domains
Instead of 10 Knowledge Areas (like Scope, Cost, Schedule), PMBOK 7 uses eight performance domains:

Team

Stakeholders

Delivery

Planning

Uncertainty & Risk

Measurement

Project Work

Development Approach & Life Cycle

Knowledge areas told you what to manage.
Performance domains emphasize how the team behaves to deliver outcomes.



4. Value Delivery Becomes the Core
PMBOK 7 embraces the idea that project management’s ultimate goal is value creation, not just scope delivery.
It introduces the Value Delivery System, which emphasizes:

Alignment to strategy

Benefits realization

Continuous flow of value

Organizational learning




5. The PM Is Now a Leader, Not a Process Administrator
PMBOK 7 elevates the project manager’s role to:

Systems thinker

Facilitator

Coach

Decision enabler

Value steward

This reflects today’s environment, where PMs must integrate technical, business, and people factors—not just maintain schedules.



6. Tailoring Is Now Essential
Tailoring has always been recommended; now it is central.
Structured tailoring considers:

Project type

Delivery approach

Governance environment

Compliance needs

Organizational capabilities

This is especially important in hybrid environments, common in aerospace, R&D, SaaS, and regulated sectors.



7. Better Alignment with Agile & Systems Thinking
While PMBOK 6 had an “Agile Practice Guide” add-on, PMBOK 7 integrates Agile-compatible concepts directly into the core framework.
It also emphasizes systems thinking, which is essential for:

Complex engineering programs

Multi-site organizations

Digital transformation

Regulatory environments




8. No More ITTO Overload
The ITTOs haven’t disappeared—they’ve been relocated to PMI’s Standards+ platform.
PMBOK 7 itself removes the 600+ ITTO details, focusing instead on principles and outcomes, streamlining guidance for real-world application.



9. Summary Table



PMBOK 6
PMBOK 7




49 Processes
12 Principles


10 Knowledge Areas
8 Performance Domains


Prescriptive
Adaptive, principles-based


ITTO-heavy
ITTO moved to Standards+


Mostly predictive
Predictive + Agile + Hybrid


Process-driven
Value-driven






10. Why This Matters
PMBOK 7 emphasizes judgment, leadership, and adaptability—skills that differentiate high-performing project managers in complex environments.
If PMBOK 6 was about “how to manage a project,” PMBOK 7 is about “how to deliver value in any environment.”



Next Post Preview
Post 3: A Practical Mapping: PMBOK 6 → PMBOK 7 Using R and Quarto

Comparison framework

R data structures to represent the mapping

Visualizing domains vs knowledge areas

Creating Quarto tables and diagrams automatically




R Code Block Example for Future Visualization
```{r} # Example: Create a simple PMBOK 6 -> 7 mapping table in R library(tibble) library(knitr)
pmbok_mapping <- tibble( PMBOK6 = c(“49 Processes”, “10 Knowledge Areas”, “Prescriptive”), PMBOK7 = c(“12 Principles”, “8 Performance Domains”, “Adaptive, principles-based”) )
kable(pmbok_mapping, caption = “PMBOK 6 vs PMBOK 7 Comparison”)
